so you know kubernetes is a great platform for running your applications
and as as with all data processing data
applications you know you're going to need to provide some data protection capabilities for for those applications
so there's a number of use cases that you need to be prepared for disaster
recovery data protection data migration and and project Valero is is one way to
help do that so in the disaster recovery use case there's a you'll be considering
ways that you can rebuild your clusters if something happens your cluster or if you choose to rebuild it to take backups

your these are times where you want to move from one cloud platform to another
perhaps sometimes just the the
complexity of kubernetes upgrades causes you to choose to rebuild a cluster
rather than doing an upgrade to a cluster and in those cases you'll want to move your data from in your
applications from one cluster to another the other use case that we're seeing quite often with with users is the the
need to hydrate or bring data into one of their tests or staging environments
from a production or other environment for for testing purposes for development
purposes and other other reasons that that they want to have data available
across a number of environments and so these are all reasons that that you
would want to use backup and restore technologies to be able to you know
provide responses for each one of these use cases so project Valero just a
little bit of background on Valero Valero is an open source tool for backing up your kubernetes clusters and
persistent volumes for your applications it works both on-premise and in public
and natively on kubernetes so Valero unlike many backup and restore utilities
isn't Driss concerned with passing a file system and picking up the files but it also is aware that kubernetes itself
is a really a running state machine that is managing the state of all of your
applications the deployments of the deployment manifest for all those applications and all that is considered
data to Valero that needs to be it needs to be backed up currently we're well
over 2,500 stars on on github we are at
version 1.0 and and as of this week we're a hundred contributor strong in
the project and we're super happy about that
Valero itself has a couple of different components one of them is a command-line interface that you can use to install
velaro to also initiate backups to create backup schedules who you know add
backup locations and targets as well as to perform restore operations so then
the on the server side is a server application a controller that operates
on a number of CR DS that are created by the Valero command line that give
instruction to the server as to how it should how it should go about performing
backups and restores so Valero seeks to
address each of the the use cases that we spoke about before so the disaster
recovery side of things Valero reduces the time to recover your
clusters in the case of some kind of infrastructure loss data corruption or other kind of service outage Valero
backs up you know all of the objects in your cluster and can in a very
very easy way recover the cluster to a new target cluster for data migration
Valero does have a lot of capabilities to allow portability of of the objects
on your cluster from one cluster to another there's also techniques which Steve will
go into a little bit later for doing things like I like transforming data
objects as they move from one cluster to another perhaps you know data objects like you know storage classes etc need
to change from one from a source to a target cluster Valera has all these kinds of capabilities and an
understanding of how to make those migrations successful the other thing
Valero is you know like kubernetes itself and many other cloud native tools
is it integrates with your DevOps workflow so you can you can use get ops
kind of strategies to to drive Valero you can also create kind of ephemeral
clones of the native namespaces so you need to do an operation on a namespace
or you need to transform a namespace from one cluster to another or or
otherwise make it available to another team or set of users it's very easy with
Valero to use the backup and restore of a namespace and Valero really
understands how to how to deal with that and how to understand what's in a namespace all the objects how to
reconstitute those objects and data volumes into another namespace successfully and so this kind of sets us
up for what we really think is kind of a future for ephemeral clusters and Valero

we think about the new paradigm of back up the Valero's is coming with as it

set themselves so the deployment resources themselves and how they're how they're handled so so we need to think

the various objects that are you know underpinning an application how they are related to one another and how they can
be reconstituted in a in a consistent way and this is what Valero endeavors to

talk a little bit about Valero's a technical approach and how we actually do that
all right thanks Tom so yeah so things are definitely a little bit more complicated in a kubernetes environment
than in a kind of a traditional IT environment when it comes to data protection and so you know the first
step to developing our data protection strategy is really to think about where is the state within a kubernetes system
and so you know the first place that that most folks think about when they think about state in kubernetes is that
@cd database that Tom alluded to so this is you know the backing store for the kubernetes api this is where all of your
deployments are defined your config maps and secrets and pods etc and so this is
this is a dynamic store of data that's going to be changing as users are deploying applications to your
kubernetes platform and so the is going to be super important to be able to to protect and to have backups
and to be able to recover and then additionally you know the second main storage state within this environment is
your you're persistent volume so this is really where your applications are storing their data and they're doing
this in a kubernetes native way using declarative definitions for these volumes but we really need to be able to
backup not just the configuration of these things but the data inside them as well in a way that's linked back to the
kubernetes application definitions when we think about the the nodes that make
up the cluster though so your masters and your workers there's not a lot of state that's inherent in these things
themselves so each of these nodes are going to be running a set of the core kubernetes components so you know on the
master will have the API server running while the controller manager running and the workers will be running the cubed
and cube proxy and other things like that but these really aren't changing very much over time they're they're
essentially a set of commodity components that can be used to define a cluster and so when we think about the
the approaches to kind of data protection for each of these components it's going to vary based on whether they
are in this kind of stateful category or in the the stateless category so next
slide please Tom
you
all right so you know starting on the left when we're talking about the nodes
and make up a kubernetes cluster you know it's our view that it's less important to think about backup and
restore here than it is to think about really using automation to make it very
trivial very straightforward to provision new infrastructure as needed
to replace to replace existing ones and so you know whether you're using ansible
puppet chef etc the the focus I think here is really on making it super easy
to stamp out a new copy of a worker node or a master node so that if you need to
replace one in your cluster you're able to do that and this applies not just for individual nodes but for clusters as
well so Tom alluded to the kind of concept of ephemeral clusters a few slides ago cluster API is a great
example of an effort that's going on in the kubernetes community to really make it very very straightforward to stamp
out new clusters based on a predefined template and so we think that's kind of the right approach to think about how to
deal with needing to replace individual nodes or clusters within a node and then once you do that there are you know
there are tools that kubernetes provides that cube control provides for safely
taking unhealthy nodes out of your clusters and swapping in a new healthy node that you've been able to stamp out
from your template on the right side though things are a little bit more complicated so with that CD and
persistent volumes you can't just reproduce these from a template these are they store dynamic data and they're
changing over time and so we do really need to think about how to be able to back these up and recover to specific
points in time next slide all right so let's let's dive into each
of those stateful components a little bit and talk about some strategies for for data protection here so starting
with Etsy D you know there are a number of different approaches we can take to protecting this data and the first two
you know block and filesystem backups basically mean that you're you're taking
either block or file level backups of the device that that EDD is storing its data on and this is you know kind of a
good basic approach it's kind of the lowest common denominator and it'll get you a certain level data protection for
that data but EDD itself is a distributed system typically runs multiple replicas and so if we really
want to get application consistent backups of this data it makes sense to
look at at the at CDC TLS capabilities for doing snapshots of the cluster in
this one this will give you application consistent backups of the entire data set that's stored within at CD but there
there isn't another approach to backing up this data and so we know that within kubernetes that CD is used to store the
data for your API resources and so you another approach to backing up this data
is to use the kubernetes api itself to actually access the data that's in that CD and store it in a backup the
kubernetes the kubernetes api provides something called a discovery API which
enables you to kind of dynamically you discover all of the different resource types that exist within the API and then
from there you're able to to capture the full definitions of each of those so this is another viable approach for for
accessing that data that's in that CD to back it up and then on the persistent volume side
we again we have a few different approaches so the first one you know is to really rely on your storage provider
now this may be a public cloud provider or may be an on-premises provider but to rely on snapshots as a way to capture a
point in time references to your data and then to be able to potentially
create durable backups from those so that you're able to restore if you need to this is typically kind of a block
level function but you can also look at taking filesystem backups of the persistent volumes that you're using
this you know would be particularly useful if you're looking at doing kind of single file recovery if that's an
important use case for you and then the you know a third option here that's emerging is is looking at the container
storage interface which is becoming a standard for kubernetes and other container orchestration systems and
looking at the emerging snapshot api's that are being added to those now those are currently in an alpha state the
upstream storage community is looking at moving these to beta relatively quickly but this this provides another kind of
integration point for being able to take point in time snapshots of the persistent volumes you're using next
slide alright so so with that background let's talk a little bit about Valero and its
approach to data protection so first of all Valero enables you to back up both
your kubernetes objects so all the kubernetes api data that's stored in at
CD as well as your applications persistent volumes so Valero covers both of these stateful components that we've
been talking about as far as the the kubernetes objects go Valera uses the
the kubernetes discovery API to access this data so it's not talking directly to add CD to backup this information and
there are a few a few different reasons that we chose this approach you know the
first one is that on a lot of managed cloud provider kubernetes platforms
you're not going to have direct access to at CD so in in things like google
kubernetes engine or a Jers kubernetes engine as a user you're not going to have direct access to at CD and so
there's there's not actually a way to do a direct backup there so we need an alternate approach beyond that though
the the API gives us a lot of capabilities that we wouldn't have even if we were doing direct at CD backups so
using the API we can do sort of fine-grained filtering and selection of the resources that we want to backup and
this also mean that when it comes time to restore we can be much more precise about what which applications which particular
resources we want to restore and then using the API also enables us to to kind
of transform this data as we're doing backups or restores so you know if you're in a migration scenario you may
actually need to make some changes to your your llamo manifest as you're restoring data into a different cluster
and so using an API driven approach gives us this opportunity to transform these resources while we're restoring
them and then Valero's stores all this data in in an object storage system
typically in the cloud and so this makes it you know makes the the lifespan of these backups exist beyond the lifespan
of your individual cluster so that if you if you lose a cluster or you need to migrate to an additional cluster you
have kind of a central location where that backup data exists and then as far
as persistent volume backup and restore so Valera uses the cloud provider
snapshot ap is the laura has a an extensible plug-in system so that
additional providers can be added as supported velaro providers without
without needing to modify the core velaro code but but this is really our
primary approach to backing up persistent volumes we also have beta
support for a file system level backup solution and we use an open source tool
called Rustique which is a generic file level backup solution and so this can be
really useful if you're maybe running on a storage provider that doesn't have snapshot api's maybe you just the little
plugin hasn't developed been developed yet for your provider or this is also really useful if you're doing cross
provider migrations because you do get a generic provider agnostic format for
your backups and then beyond that you know Valero has a variety of different
features that that help with your backup and restore workflows so it supports both ad hoc and scheduled backups as I
mentioned before there's there's some sophisticated filtering that you can do as you're backing up or restoring resources so you can select
specific namespaces to backup specific resource types you can also use label selectors to identify just the subsets
of resources that you want and it's also possible to restore resources in two
different namespaces then you back them up and so this can be really useful if you're trying to clone an existing
environment if you're trying to migrate something from maybe a dev environment to a QA environment that uses different
namespaces and then as I as I mentioned a minute ago Blair was also very
extensible so we have a plug-in mechanism so that new object and block storage providers can be added to Valero
and we also support two additional types of plugins called backup and restore
item actions and these allow you as a user of the lera to write custom bits of
logic that can actually transform resources as they're being backed up or restored so this helps you handle any
individual use cases that that you may have that aren't covered by the the core Valero platform alright next slide
so just a kind of a quick overview of what a what a standard velaro workflow
